Identification of adversary-owned or con.Action: Compare destination IPs from Zeek conn.log against lists of suspicious IPs identified by external internet scanning efforts or threat intelligence feeds associated with adversary infrastructure development. Use correlation analysis to find connections between internal hosts and suspected adversary infrastructure IPs.

Analyze Zeek conn.log and ssl.log for connections to external IPs. Look for external IPs identified by threat intelligence as exhibiting patterns (services, certificates) associated with known adversary C2 frameworks. Use filtering and correlation to identify internal hosts communicating with these IPs.

First observed internal connections to e.Action: Maintain a baseline of internal hosts and the external IPs/domains they communicate with using Zeek conn.log and dns.log. Identify internal connections to external IPs/domains that have not been observed communicating with that internal host or any internal host within a defined historical period (e.g., 90 days). Filter for suspicious ports (e.g., high ports, common C2 ports) or lack of DNS resolution. Use statistical methods (e.g., frequency analysis, set difference) to find rare or novel connections.

Suspicious command execution or outbound.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 5156; Zeek conn.log; Zeek dns.log
Suspicious command execution or outbound.Action: Correlate Windows Event ID 4688 (process creation) and 5156 (outbound connection) logs with Zeek conn.log and dns.log. Identify outbound network connections initiated by processes or user accounts that are unusual for the system or user (e.g., executable path is not standard, user account connecting from an unexpected machine). Investigate connections to external IPs/domains identified as novel or associated with suspicious ports/protocols. Use frequency analysis on process names and user accounts seen initiating external connections to identify rare occurrences and correlate with external connection data.
